aws::graph::propositions: # Embraer Phenom 300 Rudder Gust Lock Actuator Technical Analysis
Embraer commented that the gust lock actuator irreversibility is provided by a plunger commanded by a solenoid.
The spring is not able to overpower the actuator during normal operation.
The plunger provides an irreversibility function.
The force required to overpower the energized motor to extend the actuator is approximately 130N.
The force required to overpower the de-energized motor to extend the actuator is approximately 40N.
The spring force is at a maximum when the actuator is in the retracted position.
The maximum spring force is on the order of 40N.
The spring force decreases linearly to its minimum when the actuator is in the extended position.
The minimum spring force is approximately 3N.
The actuator stroke in this event was 22.4mm.
The spring force would be in the order of 7N with a 22.4mm actuator stroke.
90% of Phenom 300 fleet has incorporated a new gust lock actuator.
The new gust lock actuator is the same part number from ERJ-145 family.
The new gust lock actuator has successful operation history.
The new gust lock actuator has simplified architecture with irreversible jack screw actuation.
The new gust lock actuator does not require solenoid/plunger.
Embraer is about to release an Avionics software update.
The Avionics software update includes a CAS message.
The CAS message alerts the crew when gust lock actuator is not completely retracted.
The investigation failed to conclusively reveal the reason for the failure of the gust lock actuator solenoid.
The NTSB Systems Group Chairman's Factual Report is appended to the accident report.

subject.value: NTSB Systems Group Chairman's Factual Report

text:
# Rudder Gust Lock Actuator Irreversibility, Spring Forces, and Component Replacement - Embraer Evaluation

Additionally, Embraer commented that the irreversibility of the gust lock actuator is provided by a plunger that is commanded by a solenoid. In normal operation, the spring is not able to overpower the actuator, since the plunger provides an irreversibility function. The below listed information summarizes the forces required to overpower the actuator motor, assuming the solenoid fails in the energized position which prevents the plunger actuation (resulting in a loss of irreversibility), and the forces provided by spring:

* The force required to overpower the energized motor to extend the actuator is approximately 130N;
* The force required to overpower the de-energized motor to extend the actuator is approximately 40N;
* The spring force is at a maximum when the actuator is in the retracted position and the spring is in its maximum extended position (on the order of 40N), and it decreases linearly to its minimum when the actuator is in the extended position (~3N). Considering an actuator stroke of 22.4mm, as observed in this event, the spring force would be in the order of 7N.
* Embraer also stated that, "90% of Phenom 300 fleet has incorporated a new gust lock actuator, which is same PN from ERJ-145 family, with successful operation history and simplified architecture  irreversible jack screw actuation, which does not require solenoid/plunger. Embraer is also about to release an Avionics software update which includes a CAS message that alerts the crew when gust lock actuator is not completely retracted."

(Refer to the NTSB Systems Group Chairman's Factual Report, which is appended to this accident report.)

The investigation failed to conclusively reveal the reason for the failure of the gust lock actuator solenoid.

---
